titleStmt.title: Adaptive Finite-Time Attitude Tracking of Quadrotors with Experiments and Comparisons

affiliation.orgName: Hanchen Lu and Qun Zong are School of Elec-trical and Information Engineering

analytic.title: Adaptive Finite-Time Attitude Tracking of Quadrotors with Experiments and Comparisons

biblStruct.note: This article has been accepted for publication in a future issue of this journal, but has not been fully edited. Content may change prior to final publication. Citation information: DOI 10.1109/TIE.2019.2892698, IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: The finite-time attitude control of quadrotor unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) subject to external disturbances with unknown bound is investigated in this paper. Firstly, an adaptive multi-variable finite-time stabilizing control algorithm for second-order multi-variable systems is developed based on the improved super-twisting and the equivalent control algorithms. Furthermore, the finite-time stability conditions are derived via the Lyapunov technique. The remarkable feature of the developed algorithm is to eliminate the overestimation of the control gains without loss of the sliding motion. Then, the proposed algorithm is applied for quadrotor UAVs to solve the finite-time attitude tracking problem. Finally, a comparison of the proposed multi-variable algorithm with its scalar counterpart is presented and validated by both simulation and experiment results.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: In the last few years, the interest in quadrotor UAVs has been growing highly for civil and military applications such as aerial photography, surveillance, rescue, inspection, mapping, and agricultural monitoring. The quadrotor is a typical nonlinear and strong coupled system [1], [2], and the attitude control capable of offering an accurate orientation against various disturbances is a challenging task.

Initially, linear control methods are widely applied for quadrotor UAVs. In [3], a robust cascade proportionalintegral-derivative (PID) attitude controller was designed for quadrotor. In order to improve the control performance, robust compensators were added to reject the adverse effects due to external wind disturbances and various uncertainties. In [4], a combination of the feedback linearization and the linear quadratic regulator was proposed to stabilize the attitude of the quadrotor in the presence of disturbances. Recently, a robust mixed H 2 /H ∞ static state feedback tracking controller was proposed to achieve the attitude tracking of the quadrotor [5], and the response of the resulting closed-loop system was guaranteed by adding regional pole-placement constraints. However, the linear control methods can not guarantee the tracking performance when the quadrotor UAVs perform aggressive maneuvers.

In order to improve the flight control performance, many nonlinear control approaches have been developed [6]. In [7], a backstepping-based control strategy was developed to improve the accuracy and the robustness of the attitude controller for quadrotor UAVs, where a nonlinear disturbance observer was utilized to estimate the external disturbances. In [8], a robust nonlinear controller consisting of a sliding mode attitude control loop and a backstepping position control loop, was developed to achieve trajectory tracking of quadrotor UAVs. In [9], robust trajectory tracking control for a multirotor UAV subject to bounded external disturbances and unknown control direction is proposed within L 1 adaptive backstepping framework. It is well-known that sliding mode control is robust against matched perturbations and uncertainties. However, the sliding mode control suffering from the chattering prevents its application in practice [10]. In order to alleviate chattering effect, a family of continuous sliding mode controllers have been developed, named the super-twisting algorithms (STA) [11]. In [12], a supertwisting controller has been successfully implemented on the quadrotor to alleviate chattering and to ensure robustness with respect to bounded external disturbances. In [13], a combination between PID position controllers and continuous super-twisting attitude controller was proposed to robustly track a desired time-varying trajectory with exponential convergence. As an extension of the traditional STA, the multi-variable STA was developed and applied for the attitude control of quadrotor UAVs [14].

The upper bound of the disturbances is assumed to be known in advance by the aforementioned methods. Nevertheless, the upper bound is not always available in practice due to complicated dynamical characteristics of UAVs. The introduction of adaptive algorithm into baseline control designs such as SMC and backstepping control provides an effective way to address the issue [15], [16]. A commonly used adaptive scheme in SMC is to increase monotonically the control gain until the sliding mode is reached [17]. In [18], an adaptive sliding mode control was developed for the altitude tracking of quadrotor UAVs, where the requirement of knowing the upper bound of the uncertainties is removed. In [19], an adaptive multi-variable control algorithm based on improved STA was presented to achieve the attitude tracking of a reusable launch vehicle. However, a main drawback of the strategy is that the control gain is over-estimated with respect to the boundary of external disturbances, which would yield large chattering and cause some adverse effects on control accuracy, machine-tool life and excitation of the unmodeled dynamics [20], [21]. Hence, the non-overestimated adaptive algorithm where the control gain is as small as possible whereas sufficient to counteract the disturbances is helpful to reduce chattering. In [22], a dynamically adaptive control gains was developed, where the control gain increases before the sliding motion is established, and then the gain starts to decrease. This gain reduction shall be reversed once the system trajectory deviates from the sliding mode. This method has been applied in attitude control of a three degrees of freedom helicopter [23], where the control gain is updated online to reduce the control effort and the knowledge of the upper bound of the external disturbances is not required. The non-overestimated adaptive gain is achieved at the price of losing ideal sliding mode in the method aforementioned. Another non-overestimated adaptive algorithm is based on the equivalent control [24]. The advantage of this method is that an estimate of the disturbances is derived when the sliding motion is established, which implies that the control gain is updated in terms of the equivalent control. As a result, a less conservative control gain is achieved without overestimation. In order to address the implementation of the equivalent control in practice, an effective approximation, named average control, is provided in [25]. Also, the application of adaptive SMC was investigated in [26]. However, it can not be directly applied in attitude control of quadrotor due to the chattering and the restriction of system order. Motivated by the observations, an adaptive multi-variable continuous finite-time stabilizing control algorithm is developed to address the attitude tracking of quadrotor UAVs in the presence of unknown but bounded external disturbances. The main contributions of this paper are threefold. First, a novel adaptive multi-variable continuous finite-time stabilizing control algorithm is developed, and its application in attitude control of quadrotor UAVs is investigated. The remarkable features of the proposed algorithm are that the upper bound of the comprehensive disturbances is not required, and the ideal sliding motion can be achieved with less control effort. Second, an in-depth comparison between the multi-variable and the scalar algorithms is carried out for the first time in attitude control of quadrotor UAVs. Although some multi-variable SMC algorithms have been proposed in recent papers, such as [14], [19], [27]- [29], no comprehensive comparisons between the multi-variable algorithm and its scalar form has been reported till now to the best of our knowledge. It should be noted that our aim is not to give a conclusion on which method is better but to provide an objective investigation with regard to the application of the two algorithms in attitude control of quadrotor UAVs.

The structure of the remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section II recalls the preliminary work. The quadrotor dynamics and the problem formulation are provided in Section III. In Section VI, the adaptive multi-variable algorithm and its scalar form are presented. Section V presents the application of the both algorithms in attitude control of quadrotor UAVs. The numerical simulation and experimental validation are carried out in Section VI, where a comparative analysis on the results due to the proposed attitude controllers is also presented. Finally, concluding remarks are summarized in Section VII.

div.head: A. Notations
div.p: Throughout this paper, the following notations will be used. For a given vector x = [x 1 , .., x n ] T ∈ R n and a real number p ∈ R, define the multi-variable sign function sign(x) = x ∥x∥ , and ⌈x⌋ p = ∥x∥ p sign(x).

div.head: B. Definitions and Lemmas
div.p: Consider the nonlinear dynamical system
where x = [x 1 , .., x n ] T ∈ R n is the state vector, f (x) : R n → R n is a possibly discontinuous vector field. In this case, the solutions of (1) are understood in the sense of Filippov [30].
It is assumed that the origin is an equilibrium point of system (1).

div.head: Definition 1.
div.p: [31] The origin of system (1) is said to be globally finite time stable if it is Lyapunov stable and for any R > 0, there exists T > 0, such that any trajectory starting within the disk ∥ x ∥< R stabilizes at the origin in the time T .

Lemma 1. [32] Consider system (1), if there exists a continuously differentiable, positive definite and radically unbounded function V (x), positive scalars α ∈ (0, 1) and β > 0 such that V (x) ≤ -βV α (x). Then, the solution to system (1) converges to zero in finite time T ≤
div.formula: 1 β(1-α) V 1-α (x 0 ) with V (x 0 ) being the initial value of V (x).
div.p: Lemma 2. [19] If matrix P = [p ij ](i = 1, ..., p; j = 1, ..., p) ∈ R p×p is symmetric positive definite matrix, then the matrix P = P ⊗ I ∈ R mp×mp is also a symmetric positive definite matrix, where symbol ⊗ represents the Kronecker product.

div.head: A. Quadrotor Dynamics
div.p: The configuration of the quadrotor UAVs is shown in Fig. 1. We define an earth-fixed frame and a body-fixed frame whose origin is located at the center of mass of the rigid body. The quadrotor is composed by a rigid cross frame and four rotors. The position (x, y and z direction) and attitude (pitch, roll and yaw) motion can be achieved through an appropriate manipulation of rotors 1 to 4.

where Θ = [ϕ, θ, ψ] T is the vector of Euler angles, Ω = [p, q, r] T is the angular velocity expressed in the body-fixed frame, ∆(t) is the disturbance vector. τ = [τ 1 , τ 2 , τ 3 ] T ∈ R 3 is the control torque vector. J = diag{J xx , J yy , J zz } is the inertia matrix in the body-fixed frame, and W is defined by
div.formula: W =   1 sinϕtanθ cosϕtanθ 0 cosϕ -sinϕ 0 sinϕsecθ cosϕsecθ  (4)
div.p: The following assumption is required in the subsequent development of the control algorithm.
Assumption 1. Suppose that all the states are available for feedback, and conditions
div.formula: -π 2 < θ < π 2 and -π 2 < ϕ < π 2 hold.
div.p: Remark 1. In the present work, the quadrotor is attached to a spherical joint base (see Fig. 5) which restricts the aggressive maneuvers (i.e.,|θ| and |ϕ| approach π/2) of the vehicle. Taking into account mechanical constraints and the operating domain of the attitude dynamics of quadrotor UAVs, assumption 1 is reasonable to be used here. With this assumption, the finite-time stability obtained by the developed algorithm to be given is actually local rather than global.

div.head: B. Control Objective
div.p: The control objective of this paper is to develop a nonoverestimated adaptive multi-variable and scalar finite-time control algorithms respectively for the attitude control of quadrotor UAVs in the presence of external disturbances ∆(t) with unknown upper bound. In addition, an in-depth comparison between the two algorithms is carried out for the first time from the perspective of both theory and practice.

div.head: IV. ADAPTIVE FINITE-TIME CONTROL SCHEME WITHOUT OVER-ESTIMATION
div.p: In this section, the continuous adaptive finite-time control algorithm based on the improved STA and the equivalent control is developed for a general double integrator systems with bounded but unknown disturbances.

div.p: Step 2. In what follows, it will be illustrated that the adaptive gain ρ(t) > || ∆(t)|| holds after a finite time interval.

Note the fact that the extended equivalent control is applied for a complete system motion, including on and outside the sliding motion [35]. For system (13), the extended equivalent control z eq satisfies ||z eq (t)|| = ||b(t)⌈s 1 ⌋ 0 || = b 0 ρ(t) outside of the sliding motion, and ||z eq (t)|| = || ∆(t)|| during the sliding motion. Thus, during the reaching phase, the adaptive law (11) is governed by

V3 in (45) satisfies V3 ≤ (k M + 1)V 3 + L. Hence, V 3 is bounded in any finite time interval. This completes the proof.

Remark 2. The extended equivalent control z eq is used in adaptive law (11). In practice, it can be derived by the low pass filter λ żav + z av = b(t)⌈s 1 ⌋ 0 with λ being a filter time constant. Hence, the extended equivalent control z eq can be replaced by its approximating value z av with certain accuracy. With respect to the appropriate selection of τ , the readers can The developed algorithm is designed based on multi-variable structure, which will yield some promising properties, such as non-decoupled design and chattering attenuation (see Fig. 3).

div.head: V. APPLICATION TO ATTITUDE CONTROL OF QUADROTOR UAVS
A. Attitude Error Dynamics
div.p: In this subsection, the attitude error dynamics is derived based on ( 2) and (3). Specifically, denote e 1 = Θ-Θ ref by the attitude tracking error vector, where
div.formula: Θ ref = [ϕ ref , θ ref , ψ ref ] T
div.p: represents the desired attitude command. Let e 2 = W Ω -Θref be the angular velocity tracking error in the earth-fixed frame. Taking into account the attitude model ( 2) and ( 3), the attitude error dynamics of quadrotor UAVs can be described by
div.formula: ė1 =e 2 ė2 = -W J -1 Ω × J Ω -Θref + Ẇ Ω F + W J -1 τ τ ′ + W J -1 ∆(t) ∆ ′ (t)(49)
div.p: where
div.formula: e 1 = [e 1ϕ , e 1θ , e 1ψ ] T , e 2 = [e 2ϕ , e 2θ , e 2ψ ] T , F = [F 1 , F 2 , F 3 ] T , τ ′ = [τ ′ 1 , τ ′ 2 , τ ′ 3 ] T represents the virtual control input, and ∆ ′ (t) = [∆ ′ 1 (t), ∆ ′ 2 (t), ∆ ′ 3 (t)] T is the disturbance vector.
div.p: For the sake of using the developed scalar algorithm in Lemma 3, the component-wise form of (49) is formulated as follows

To proceed, the following assumption is required Assumption 3. Suppose that the external disturbance ∆ ′ (t) in (49) is Lipschitz continuous, i.e., its derivative exists and the inequality ∥ ∆′ (t) ∥≤ δ 1 holds almost everywhere with δ 1 being an unknown constant, which implies that each component of ∆ ′ (t) (∆ ′ i (t) in (51)) is also Lipschitz continuous almost everywhere.

div.head: B. Finite-time Attitude Controller
div.p: In view of multi-variable attitude error dynamics (49) and its corresponding component-wise form (50) and (51), the adaptive multi-variable and scalar finite-time attitude controllers are developed based on Theorem 1 and Lemma 3, respectively. The main results in the subsection is summarized in the following lemmas. Lemma 4. Consider attitude error dynamic system (49) with assumption 3, if the control input vector τ ′ is designed by
div.formula: where σ = e 2 + ∫ t 0 (k 1 ⌈e 1 ⌋ ϱ 1 2-ϱ 1 + k 2 ⌈e 2 ⌋ ϱ1 )dt and Γ(t) = -ρ 2ρ σ [I-σσ T 2||σ|| 2 ]
div.p: , and parameters k 1 , k 2 , ϱ 1 , a(t), b(t) and adaptive law ρ(t) are selected according to Theorem 1. Then, the attitude tracking error e 1 converge to zero in finite time.
Lemma 5. Consider attitude error dynamic system (49) with assumption 3, if the control inputs τ ′ i , i = 1, 2, 3 are designed by
div.formula: τ ′ 1 = -F1 -k11|e 1ϕ | ϱ 11 2-ϱ 11 sign(e 1ϕ ) -k12|e 2ϕ | ϱ 11 sign(e 2ϕ ) -a1ρ 1 2 1 |σ1| 1 2 sign(σ1) - ∫ t 0 b1ρ1sign(σ1)dt - ρ1 ρ1 σ1 (53) τ ′ 2 = -F2 -k21|e 1θ | ϱ 21 2-ϱ 21 sign(e 1θ ) -k22|e 2θ | ϱ 21 sign(e 2θ ) -a2ρ 1 2 2 |σ2| 1 2 sign(σ2) - ∫ t 0 b2ρ2sign(σ2)dt - ρ2 ρ2 σ2 (54) τ ′ 3 = -F3 -k31|e 1ψ | ϱ 31 2-ϱ 31 sign(e 1ψ ) -k32|e 2ψ | ϱ 31 sign(e 2ψ ) -a3ρ 1 2 3 |σ3| 1 2 sign(σ3) - ∫ t 0 b3ρ3sign(σ3)dt - ρ3ρ3
div.p: with parameters k ij and ϱ i1 , i = 1, 2, 3, j = 1, 2 are selected by a similar form in Lemma 3. Then, the attitude tracking errors e 1ϕ , e 1θ and e 1ψ converge to zero in finite time.
With the virtual control moment given in ( 52) or ( 53) to (55), the real control moment can be calculated by τ = J W -1 τ ′ (see ( 49)) due to the non-singularity of matrix W under assumption 1.

div.head: A. Parameter Setting
div.p: The physical parameters for the quadrotor UAVs are summarized as follows:

div.head: B. Numerical Results
div.p: The tracking errors of the Euler angles are provided in Fig. 2. From Fig. 2, it can be seen that the tracking errors converge to zero after some finite time even in the presence of disturbance without any information about its upper bound. The zoomed figures in Fig. 2 illustrate that the tracking accuracy achieved by the proposed controllers. Specifically, for multi-variable algorithm, the roll tracking accuracy is about 5 × 10 -5 degree, and the pitch as well as the yaw tracking accuracy are about 4 × 10 -5 degree and 2 × 10 -5 degree, respectively. Fig. 2 demonstrates that the attitude tracking accuracies achieved by scalar algorithm are much higher, which are about 10 -6 deg, 5 × 10 -7 deg and 5 × 10 -8 deg for roll, pitch and yaw, respectively. The control signals are shown in Fig. 3, where the more smooth control behavior can be observed from the multivariable algorithm. Furthermore, the adaptive gains obtained by the multi-variable and the scalar algorithms are plotted in Fig. 4. From Fig. 4, it can be observed that the gains vary in accordance with the amplitude of the external disturbances, which implies that the developed adaptive algorithm is nonoverestimated. Hence, the simulation results demonstrate the efficiency of the proposed controllers in attitude tracking with high accuracy and fast convergent rate.

div.head: C. Experiment Validation
div.p: In this subsection, experimental results are provided to validate the performance of the developed algorithms. The controller parameters are identical to those in numerical examples discussed in the previous subsection. The quadrotor platform is shown in Fig. 5, where the quadrotor is attached to a spherical joint base which restricts the translational motion of the vehicle. In this testbed, the Rpi-3b with autopilot . With these reference commands, the quadrotor performs hover and maneuver, as shown in Fig. 5. The corresponding experimental results are shown in Fig. 6 to Fig. 9. Fig. 6 illustrates the performance of the multi-variable and the scalar algorithms in achieving attitude tracking of the quadrotor, which exhibit good closed-loop performance. The attitude tracking errors are plotted in Fig. 7. From zoomed subplots in Fig. 7, it can be seen that the tracking accuracies of roll angle and pitch angle are similar within the scope of 1 degree. However, the scalar algorithm shows a better control performance than multi-variable algorithm in yaw channel, which can be observed from the bottom plot of Fig. 7. The adaptive gain due to the multi-variable algorithm is shown in Fig. 8(a), and the ones due to the scalar algorithm in roll, pitch and yaw channel are plotted in Fig. 8(b) to Fig. 8(d), respectively. Finally, the control torques are given in Fig. 9.
From these results, it can be observed that the the attitude tracking with satisfactory performance can be achieved by the developed methods in practice.

div.head: D. Discussions
div.p: In this subsection, some comparisons between the multivariable and the scalar algorithms are carried out based on the simulation and the experiment results.

(I) In theory, the scalar algorithm exhibits a better control accuracy than the multi-variable algorithm, which can be seen from the results in Fig. 2. It is well known that the sliding mode control has complete robustness and high control accuracy for systems with matched disturbances due to the sign function, i.e., sign(σ i ), i = (1, 2, 3) in (56) to (58), which is discontinuous at σ i = 0. Nevertheless, for multi-variable algorithm, the sign function, i.e., ⌊σ⌉ 0 = σ ∥σ∥ in (52), is discontinuous only when all the components of σ to zero simultaneously. This results in the different tracking accuracies between the two algorithms. With the same reason, multi-variable algorithm shows better property in chattering attenuation, which can be viewed from the results in Fig. 3. However, the proof of finite-time stability of the closed-loop system under multi-variable controller is more involved than the scalar one due to the fact that some scalar operations have to be replaced by matrix operations in multi-variable algorithm.

(II) In practice, the similar control performance can be achieved by the two algorithms, as shown in Fig. 7. However, we find that the parameter tuning for the multi-variable controller is much easier than the scalar algorithm especially in the experimental settings. In the beginning, the scalar controller

parameters for the roll, the pitch and the yaw channels are selected to be the same as those for multi-variable controller. However, the control performance under the scalar controller is poor. By many trial and errors, the parameters in Table II are used in the simulation and the real-time flight test.

div.head: VII. CONCLUSION
div.p: A continuous finite-time control algorithm is proposed for attitude tracking of quadrotor UAVs subject to unknown external disturbances. An adaptive control gain is developed to ensure that the attitude tracking can be achieved in finite time without overestimation. A rigorous proof of finite-time stability of the closed-loop system under the developed algorithm is derived through the Lyapunov technique. Furthermore, the control performance of the developed multi-variable algorithm and its scalar counterpart on quadrotor UAVs is compared based on the simulation results and the real-time flight test results. The extension of the developed algorithm to attitude control of quadrotor UAVs with input saturation will be considered in the future.

10 -3 kg • m 2 . In this simulation, the filter time constant λ = 0.002 is used. In addition, the disturbances ∆(t) = [1 + 2sin(t); 1 + cos(t); 1 + 0.5(sin(t) + cos(t))] T are added. The desired reference command is selected as Θ ref = [0.1sin(t), 0.1cos(t), 0.1] T rad. The initial values of the attitude angles and the angular velocities are set to Θ(0) = [0.2, 0.2, 0.2] T rad and Ω(0) = [0, 0, 0] T rad/s.
